description:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/4491/

What caused this is trying to unrescue the instance while the rescue volume was still mounted (/dev/xvdb was mounted).

This puts the instance in ERROR, effectively ruining a perfectly good instance.

A couple of different options are possible here:

1. Leave instance in rescuing with a helpful reminder to try to unmount VM.

nova unrescue <BLAH>
Error: unable to shutdown rescue vm, is the rescue volume still mounted?

2. Use cold-plugged VBDs

Right now we're hotplugging the VBDs, but this is unecessary and a bit dangerous (more can go wrong). As an alternative we can cold-plug the VBDs, so by the time the instance has shutdown the VBDs should be free to destroy.

This may require us to --force the shutdown, which is a similar issue, it's dangerous since the volume is mounted, but there may not be another solution here. Especially since we probably want to timeout rescue VMs eventually.
title: Unrescue fails when volume still mounted

comments.content:
I'm able to unrescue a vm with a volume mounted on it. I'm working essex version of nova(2012.1~e4~20120227.12935-0ubuntu0ppa1~oneiric1) and i'm following the steps below to reproduce the bug:
1. Boot a VM
2. Attach a volume to it.
3. RESCUE the VM
4. UNRESCUE the VM.

And i'm not facing any problem with it. 

Did i miss anything?
